content:
type app is an android email application per Google. Thunderbird is also an email application, be it on Android or one of the other supported operating systems.

If you could offer any sort of reasoning as what the two have to do with one another it would be most helpful. My initial feeling is it is like having a BMW and a Audi in the garage. Both are cars made mostly in Europe but they have nothing to do with one another except share an owner and parking place.

content:
Thanks for your message! You're referring to a known issue in Thunderbird Address Book version 145 (and similar builds), where drag-and-drop into mailing lists (also called distribution lists) no longer works as it did in earlier versions.

‚úÖ The problem: In Thunderbird 115+ (including 145), the address book has been redesigned, and drag & drop behavior is broken or changed:

- You can't drag individual contacts from the main address book into a mailing list anymore. - The mailing list UI doesn't accept dropped items as before.

üí° Workarounds / Solutions: üõ† 1. Manually Add Contacts to the Mailing List

You can still: 1. Open the mailing list by double-clicking it. 2. In the window that opens, type the name or email address of the contact manually. Thunderbird auto-completes based on your address book. 3. Click OK / Save when finished. ‚ö†Ô∏è This is tedious for large lists, but still works.

üîÑ 2. Switch to ‚ÄúClassic‚Äù Address Book (if possible) Some users have had success using older Thunderbird versions (e.g. 102.x), where drag & drop still works. - You can install an older portable Thunderbird version alongside the new one for managing contacts.

üß© 3. Use an Add-on (if available) Some Thunderbird extensions (like "Mailing List Tools" or "CardBook") have reintroduced better list handling. Keep an eye on: - https://addons.thunderbird.net - Search for Mailing list management tools or Cardbook üîç Compatibility with Thunderbird 145 must be confirmed before use.

‚è≥ 4. Wait for Fixes This is a known issue, and many users have https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/ and the https://support.mozilla.org/

üëâ Developers are likely aware and may fix it in a future update.

üîö Summary | Option | Status | | ----------------- | ------------------------- | | Drag & Drop | ‚ùå Currently broken | | Manual entry | ‚úÖ Works, but tedious | | Older Thunderbird | ‚úÖ Drag & drop works there | | Add-ons | üîÑ May help | | Future updates | ‚è≥ Likely fix coming |
creator: Germanus

content:
Try this: - exit thunderbird - copy the profile to wherever you desire - restart thunderbird - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles' - click 'create profile' - click next - enter a shortcut name, such as NEWPROFILE - then, click the 'choose' button and select the profile you copied and launch - once satisfied, you can delete the old profile

Another approach is to - exit thunderbird - copy profile to wherever - edit the profile.ini file to point to new location - restart thunderbird - if content, delete the old profile

content:
Have you tried using the AOL settings that also work with e.g. verizon.net accounts?

incoming IMAP server: imap.aol.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = email address

incoming POP server: pop.aol.com, 995, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = email address

outgoing SMTP server: smtp.aol.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = email address

https://help.compuserve.com/articles/how-do-i-use-other-email-applications-to-send-and-receive-my-aol-mail

Enter the account (not app) password in the OAuth window to allow access. Cookies must be accepted in TB (not browser) Settings for OAuth to complete.
creator: sfhowes

content:
THANK YOU. Here is what I did. Incoming mail was fine and already was imap.aol.com I don't use POP so I did nothing with that. Outgoing I changed from smtp.compuserve.com to smtp.aol.com; security was fine and I changed from Normal PW to OAuth2.

Worked fine on my SurfaceGO but on my main laptop, even though I verified all settings and PWs were correct I had to reboot to get it to work.

I guess AOL changed something even though went I went to their website earlier today it gave me a new app-specific PW and I tried that and it did not work.

ANYWAY - THANK YOU THANK YOU. Any further thoughts?
creator: eberger5

content: An app password is only needed if the mail app only supports 'normal password' authentication instead of OAuth2. I use that on my phone with an AOL account in the gmail app. But since TB supports OAuth2 for AOL since a few years, that is the preferred method.

content:
I have saved some notes from others who posted here with Comcast issues, so maybe some of these links will be useful:

The correct incoming server is imap.comcast.net for IMAP or pop3.comcast.net for POP, plus you have to enable access to the account by mail apps like TB: Set Port to 587 Set Connection Security to : STARTTLS for SMTP smtp.comcast.net, normal password 

https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/third-party-email-access https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/email-client-programs-with-xfinity-email https://www.xfinity.com/support/articles/third-party-email-access

content:
IMAP synchronizes server folders between the e-mail client (Thunderbird) and the server, as you see. Trash is a server folder.

Did you not have what you wanted with POP?

Edit: oh, I misunderstood the direction of your intended change.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Rick said
IMAP synchronizes server folders between the e-mail client (Thunderbird) and the server, as you see. Trash is a server folder. Did you not have what you wanted with POP?

Hi Rick, thanks your reply. I thought I'd switched from IMAP to POP, but now I'm not so sure. Under Server Settings I replaced the imap.myserver.com.au address with pop.myserver.com.au. However, the heading above the address still says "Server Type: IMAP Server", and it's still uploading to Trash as before.

I've looked high and low without being able to find instructions on how to switch Thunderbird desktop from IMAP to POP!
creator: mrstaemin7

content: You cannot switch. You set up a new account in Thunderbird with the protocol that you want. After that, when you're happy with everything, you can delete the previous account with the other protocol. Of course, depending on your accounts, settings, folders, et cet., you may have to do some other things to save messages. Making a back-up copy before doing anything like this is always a good idea.
creator: mozilla98
